Title: Targeting of dissidents and opposition political candidates in Ghana
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Ghana's government
Description: The Israeli spyware firm NSO Group sold Pegasus spyware to the government of Ghana, which used the tools to spy on political opponents and dissidents. Ghana's intelligence agency launched an investigation into the spyware allegations. NSO Group has claimed that although Ghana bought the spyware, it was never actually used in the country.?
Victims: Political dissidents and opposition leaders in Ghana

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian state entities
Description: The Belarusian threat actor UNC1151 targeted multiple Ukrainian government agencies with a backdoor called MicroBackdoor. The malware??as delivered via phishing emails that included a bait image and files containing malicious code. The backdoor and loader were created in January 2022, before Russia?? invasion of Ukraine.??

Title: Targeting of Russian and Belarusian websites
Description: Ukraine?? IT Army compromised Docker Engine honeypots in an attempt to execute distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks against Russian and Belarusian websites.
Victims: Russian and Belarusian websites were targeted, including those belonging to government, military, media, finance, energy, retail, mining, manufacturing, chemicals, production, technology, advertisements, agriculture, transportation, and political parties.

Title: Targeting of the Belgian Federal Public Service Interior in Chinese espionage campaign
Description: Chinese threat actors targeted the Belgian Federal Public Service Interior as part of a wide-ranging cyberespionage campaign involving multiple threat actors. Belgian authorities condemned the activity.

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian government agencies
Description:
The Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine found that Gamaredon had been breaking into Ukrainian government email accounts.
?

Title: Targeting of Palestinian entities and activists
Description: The Hamas-linked threat actor APT-C-23 used malware embedded in politically themed decoy files and documents to install backdoors on the systems of targeted Palestinian individuals and organizations.??

Title: Targeting of government agencies in the European Union
Description: Russian threat actor Gamaredon targeted Ukrainian organizations in a phishing campaign. The hackers sent malicious emails with lures related to the Russia-Ukraine conflict, including attachments labeled ??nformation on war criminals of the Russian Federation??and ??ecessary_military_assistance.??The emails contained malware which allowed Russian operators to conduct espionage.
Victims: Government agencies of EU member states

Title: Targeting of Rostec
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Chinese government
Description: A Chinese threat actor targeted two research institutes run by Rostec, a major Russian state-owned defense conglomerate. The attackers used spear-phishing lures to plant malware and steal data on Russian radar and electronic warfare capabilities.
Victims: Two research institutes run by Rostec

Title: Targeting of Albanian government
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Iranian government
Description: Iranian threat actors targeted Albanian government networks with ransomware. The attack appears to have been motivated by Albania?? hosting a conference for the People?? Mojahedin Organization of Iran, a group previously listed as a terrorist organization by the European Union (EU) and United States and dedicated to opposing the Iranian regime.

Title: Targeting of users of cryptocurrency applications
Description:
North Korean hacking group Lazarus created a fake brand called BloxHolder to spread fake cryptocurrency apps that would infect users with AppleJeus malware to steal money and cryptocurrency. The campaign was active from June to at least October 2022.
?

Title: Targeting of VMWare Horizon servers with Log4Shell vulnerability
Description: The Iranian threat actor APT 35 leveraged the Log4Shell vulnerability to run malicious PowerShell commands, deploy backdoors, steal credentials, and move laterally through systems.??

Title: Targeting of cryptocurrency company employees
Description: North Korean hackers targeted cryptocurrency company employees in a phishing campaign to access systems and make fraudulent trades. Lazarus sent mass emails with job offers embedded with malicious links. When victims clicked, their devices downloaded TraderTraitor malware, which enabled the hackers to execute commands and infiltrate company networks to make fraudulent blockchain transactions.

Title: Targeting of individual suspects in serious criminal investigations within Canada
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Canadian government
Description: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) has confirmed that it uses spyware to infiltrate the mobile devices of suspects in highly sensitive criminal and national security investigations. From 2018 to 2020, the RCMP said it used spyware in ten investigations.
Victims: Individual suspects within Canadian police investigations.

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian government agencies in espionage campaign
Description: Gamaredon, a Russian threat actor, was found using newly developed malware to steal information from Ukrainian government agencies. The malware was distributed through a phishing campaign.

Title: Targeting of Israeli activist
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Israel's government.
Description: The Israeli government used the NSO Group's spyware tool Pegasus to spy on an Israeli activist. The authorities allegedly catalogued his activity on a dating site for use as future leverage.?

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian government and IT sector systems with WhisperGate malware
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Russian government
Description: The Russian Army?? Main Intelligence Directorate (the GRU) used WhisperGate wiper malware on Ukrainian systems on January 13, 2022. The wiper masqueraded as ransomware, offering victims the chance to decrypt their data for a fee, while in reality, the malware wiped the system. The wiper was found on systems throughout Ukraine, including the foreign ministry and networks used by the Ukrainian cabinet.
Victims: Ukrainian government and IT sector systems

Title: Targeting of Belgian Defense Ministry
Description: Chinese threat actors targeted the Belgian Defense Ministry as part of a wide-ranging cyberespionage campaign involving multiple threat actors, which also targeted the Interior Service. Belgian authorities condemned the activity.

Title: Targeting of Uyghur populations
Description: Chinese-affiliated threat actor APT 15 led a mobile surveillance campaign against Uyghurs in China and abroad using BadBazaar malware masquerading as Android apps.?
Victims: Members of the Uyghur ethnic group

Title: Targeting of Jordanian activists
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Jordanian government
Description: The devices of at least four Jordanian human rights activists, lawyers, and journalists were infected with NSO Group?? Pegasus spyware between August 2019 and December 2021. Two Pegasus operators involved in the incident, named Mansaf and BlackIris, are likely connected to agencies of the Jordanian government.
Victims: Four Jordanian human rights defenders, lawyers, and journalists

Title: Targeting of Tibetans living abroad
Description: A Chinese threat actor was found using a zero-day vulnerability, dubbed Follina, in Microsoft Office products to distribute zero-click malware. The attackers used Follina to target Tibetan organizations and Tibetans living abroad with malware.
Victims: Tibetan organizations and Tibetans living abroad

Title: Targeting of Australian, Malaysian, and European organizations and organizations operating in and around the South China Sea.
Description: APT 40 launched an espionage campaign targeting Australian, European, and Asian organizations involved in maintaining and producing wind turbines in the South China Sea, as well as Malaysian organizations working in the Kasawari gas field.
Victims: Australian, Canadian, German, Japanese, Norwegian, Swedish, and Taiwanese organizations involved in wind turbine maintenance and production, as well as Malaysian oil and gas refineries.

Title: Targeting of Latvian, Lithuanian, and Ukrainian computer systems
Description: Russian threat actors targeted computer systems in Latvia, Lithuania, and Ukraine with a wiper dubbed HermeticWiper. The malware was aimed at Windows devices, corrupting systems??master boot records, displaying signs of ransomware as a decoy, and destroying stored data. This followed another wiper attack aimed at Ukraine in January.?
Victims: Latvian, Lithuanian, and Ukrainian computer systems owned by banks and government contractors, as well as systems used by the defense, aviation, and IT sectors

Title: Targeting of journalists reporting on North Korea
Description: North Korea??inked threat actor APT 37 targeted journalists with novel Goldbackdoor malware. APT 37 initially used RokRat malware to hack the email account of a former director at South Korea?? National Intelligence Service. The hackers then impersonated the official and targeted South Korean journalists, sending emails laced with Goldbackdoor malware. The malware can be used to steal passwords and documents.
Victims: Journalists and the former director of South Korea?? National Intelligence Service

Title: Targeting of UN Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL)
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Iranian government
Description: The Israeli defense minister has accused Iran and Hezbollah of attempting a cyberattack against the UNIFIL to steal information about its activities within southern Lebanon.

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian networks via fake telecommunications firms
Description: A Russian threat actor masqueraded as a Ukrainian telecommunications firm in order to gain access to other networks in Ukraine, both through spear-phishing and malicious public domains.
Victims: Ukrainian telecommunications infrastructure and other firms

Title: Targeting of local Israeli officials
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Israel's government
Description: The signals intelligence unit of the Israeli police is suspected of using Pegasus spyware to surveil local officials and their families in Israel. The warrantless surveillance conducted with Pegasus was used to inform later prosecutions for bribery, some of which were dismissed in court for lack of evidence. The police attempted to cover up evidence that they had used Pegasus in the investigations.?
Victims: Mayors and other local officials in Israel.

Title: Targeting of Asus routers
Description: Sandworm targeted WatchGuard and ASUS routers with Cyclops Blink malware, an advanced modular botnet. The malware gives Sandworm access to data and files stored on compromised networks. The malware affects devices??hat do not belong to critical organizations, suggesting that its purpose may be to build infrastructure for later attacks on high-value targets.?
Victims: Asus Routers in countries including the United States, Canada, India, Italy, and Russia

Title: Targeting of government network in Vinnytsia, Ukraine
Description: APT 28 conducted phishing campaigns targeting the Ukrainian military and government employees. Strontium succeeded in compromising a government network in Vinnytsia, a city in western Ukraine.

Title: Targeting of European Union (EU) member states
Description: A North Korean advanced persistent threat group used malware known as Konni, a remote-access Trojan, to hack into high-level organizations across the EU.
Victims: Czech Republic, Poland, and other EU countries

Title: Targeting of Polish and Ukrainian transportation companies
Description: Russian threat actor Sandworm targeted transportation and logistics organizations in Ukraine and Poland with Prestige ransomware starting in October 2022.

Title: Antlion
Description: Antlion is a Chinese threat actor suspected of targeting organizations in Taiwan using custom backdoors to deploy both custom and off-the-shelf malware. Antlion has conducted extended espionage campaigns against private sector companies.?
Victims: Financial departments of Taiwanese private sector companies

Title: Targeting of Israeli officials
Description: Hamas-linked actor APT-C-23 targeted Israelis with an espionage campaign to exfiltrate sensitive information from individuals working in law enforcement, the military, and emergency services. The attackers used fabricated Facebook profiles to lure targets to install trojanized direct message applications.
Victims: Israeli individuals including a group of high-profile targets working for defense, law enforcement, and emergency services organizations

Title: Targeting of Boston Children?? Hospital
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Iranian government.
Description: Iranian government-backed hackers are believed to have launched a ransomware attack against the Boston Children's Hospital in the summer of 2021. The attack was foiled after a partner country shared intelligence with the FBI.

Title: Targeting of industrial enterprises and public institutions in Central Asia and Eastern Europe
Description: Chinese hackers used phishing emails to plant PortDoor malware on the systems of industrial organizations in Afghanistan, Belarus, Russia, and Ukraine. Security researchers detected the hackers exfiltrating data to a server with a Chinese IP address.
Victims: Industrial plants, design bureaus, research institutes, and government organizations in Afghanistan, Belarus, Russia, and Ukraine.

Title: Targeting of Chinese users with three zero days
Description:
Ocean Lotus, a Vietnamese APT, was found deploying three zero days on Chinese networks. The attacks were primarily directed at gaining and expanding access to routers, networks, and cameras in China. Ocean Lotus could have also incorporated some of the compromised devices into its Torii botnet.
?

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian and Polish military personnel
Description: Belarusian threat actor UNC1151 targeted the private email addresses of Ukrainian soldiers in a phishing attack. UNC1151 hacked the email accounts of military personnel and then leveraged the compromised address books to send further malicious emails, many of which were sent to Polish military personnel.?

Title: Targeting of Russian military officials
Description: Chinese threat actor Mustang Panda targeted Russian government computer systems with PlugX malware. The malware was disguised in a malicious file masquerading as a PDF, which was named after a Russian border guard unit.

Title: Targeting of Hungarian Foreign Ministry networks
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the government of the Russian Federation.
Description: The Federal Security Service and the Russian military intelligence agency have conducted cyberattacks against the Hungarian Foreign Ministry since at least 2012 to retrieve critical information Hungary?? diplomatic relations with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European Union (EU).

Title: Targeting of governments in the Middle East and Africa
Description: APT 10 installed web shells on public-facing servers and extracted information from Middle Eastern governments and an African stock exchange.
Victims: Two Middle Eastern countries and one African stock exchange

Title: Earth Lusca
Description: Earth Lusca is a threat actor that targets organizations of interest to the Chinese government, including academic institutions, telecommunication companies, religious organizations, and other civil society groups. Earth Lusca's tools closely resemble those used by Winnti Umbrella, but the group appears to operate separately from Winnti. Earth Lusca has also been observed targeting cryptocurrency payment platforms and cryptocurrency exchanges in what are likely financially motivated attacks.?
Victims: Academic institutions, government research organizations, religious groups, cryptocurrency exchanges, and other financial and civil society organizations.

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian state bodies
Description: Russian APT??nvisiMole, which has ties to Gamaredon, conducted a phishing campaign targeting Ukrainian organizations with the LoadEdge backdoor. The backdoor allowed Gamaredon to install surveillance software and other malware onto infected systems.?

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian organizations with CaddyWiper
Description: Sandworm targeted Ukrainian organizations with CaddyWiper malware, destroying user data hosted on several dozen systems. Evidence suggests Sandworm infiltrated the targets??networks before installing the wiper.
Victims: Ukrainian critical infrastructure and government systems

Title: Targeting of South Korea with multiple spear-phishing campaigns
Description: A North Korean threat actor targeted South Korean government agencies, think tanks, and companies in the defense, education, energy, and medical-care sectors using spear- phishing campaigns to extract confidential information.
Victims: South Korean defense, education, medical, and energy companies and government agencies

Title: Targeting of U.S. federal agency
Description: Iran-affiliated group Nemesis Kitten targeted an unnamed U.S. federal agency, though suspected to be the U.S. Merit Systems Protections Board, and installed cryptocurrency-mining software into the government agency's network.

Title: Targeting of journalists at News Corp
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of China's government.
Description: A Chinese threat actor hacked the email accounts of journalists employed at American media company News Corp. The attackers aimed to uncover journalists??sources, as well as drafts of upcoming articles. No consumer or financial data was compromised.?
Victims: The email accounts of several journalists working for News Corp headquarters, News Technology Services, Dow Jones, News UK, and the New York Post

Title: Targeting of organizations in Asia, Europe, and North America
Description: Chinese threat actor APT 10 used a vulnerability in Microsoft Exchange to gain access to victims??networks, where the attackers deployed a custom loader and the Sodamaster backdoor. APT 10 also used a custom loader to obtain credentials. The attackers spent up to nine months in victims??networks.
Victims: Government, legal, religious, and nongovernmental organizations in Asia, Europe, and North America

Title: Targeting of Palauans via an Australian telecommunications company
Description: Chinese threat actor APT 40 was found using a zero-day in Microsoft Office products, dubbed Follina, as part of a spear-phishing campaign against targets in Palau.
Victims: Australian telecommunications networks and a group of Palauan users

Title: Targeting of Northwestern Polytechnical University
Affiliations: National Security Agency, Tailored Access Operations
Description: China accused the U.S. National Security Agency (NSA) of hacking into the networks of Northwestern Polytechnical University, a prominent defense research university in Xi'an, in June 2022. Some researchers expressed doubt at the claims, as the report accused the NSA of using a tool more than ten years old that was leaked more than five years ago.

Title: Targeting of Citrix Systems software
Description:
The U.S. National Security Agency issued a warning that two pieces of software from Citrix Systems, which are commonly used in corporate servers, had major vulnerabilities that were being actively exploited by APT 5.
?
Victims: Users of Citrix Systems' application delivery controller and Gateway endpoint

Title: Targeting of Moscow Stock Exchange and Sberbank websites
Description: Hackers from Ukraine?? IT Army targeted the websites of the Moscow Stock Exchange and Russian lender Sberbank with a DDoS attack. The incident was planned and conducted through posts on Telegram channels and other social media directing thousands of members to attack specified targets.?
Victims: Moscow Stock Exchange and Sberbank websites

Title: Targeting of Catalan separatists
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Spanish government
Description: The devices of at least sixty-five pro-independence Catalans were targeted with Pegasus and Candiru spyware. Most of the incidents occurred between 2017 and 2020, amid rising tensions over Catalan separatism and the 2017 Catalan independence referendum. Analysts found evidence on the victims??devices of ??ero-click??exploits, which infect phones and computers even without users clicking on malicious links. Reports indicate Spain?? intelligence service had prior court approval to use the spyware to target Catalan separatists.
Victims: The identified victims include the president of the Catalan government, members of the European Parliament, Catalan legislators, and activists

Title: Targeting of pro-democracy organizations and activists in Thailand
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the government of Thailand.
Description: Pegasus spyware was used to hack the phones of pro-democracy groups and individuals in Thailand.
Victims: Pro-democracy organizations and activists in Thailand

Title: Targeting of medical professionals
Description:
As part of a larger Iranian espionage campaign against medical professionals, TA453 targeted an individual with a spear-phishing lure to gain access to their credentials. The earlier campaign, known as BadBlood, targeted researchers in the United States and Israel, although the location of the researcher targeted in this latest attack remains unclear.
?

Title: Targeting of Middle Eastern government institutions in phishing campaign
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Hamas.
Description: The Palestinian threat actor Molerats launched a spear-phishing attack by sending malicious documents to government departments across the Middle East. The documents were ostensibly an analysis of the conflict between Israel and Palestine.??
Victims: Government institutions in the Middle East

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian government officials
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of China's government
Description: The Chinese threat actor Scarab targeted Ukrainian government officials with lure documents used to load HeaderTip malware onto target systems. The lure documents mimic releases from the National Police of Ukraine.?

Title: Targeting of major Ukrainian broadcasting company
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Russian government
Description: Russian threat actors targeted a major broadcasting company with the DesertBlade wiper. This incident followed the Russian military?? announcement that it would destroy Ukrainian disinformation targets.

Title: Targeting of military personnel, government officials, employees of human rights and other nonprofit organizations, and students in Afghanistan, India, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates (UAE)
Description: A Pakistani advanced persistent threat actor used emails and social media to target people online and plant malware on their devices.
Victims: Military personnel, government officials, employees of human rights and other nonprofit organizations, and students in Afghanistan, India, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE

Title: Targeting of Asian and Australian governments and government partners
Description:
China-affiliated APT Mustang Panda conducted a spear-fishing campaign against several Asian governments starting in March 2022. Mustang Panda used two new malware families, Toneins and Toneshell, in the campaign.
?
Victims: Asian government agencies??including Japan, Myanmar, the Philippines, and Taiwan??and the Australian government

Title: Targeting of Middle Eastern governments, foreign policy think tanks, and a state-affiliated airline
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Palestine's government
Description: The Palestinian threat actor Molerats targeted Middle Eastern governments, foreign policy think tanks, and a state-affiliated airline with spear-phishing emails containing a remote access Trojan. To avoid detection, Molerats used geofencing and URL redirects to legitimate sites. The hackers masqueraded as the site Quora and also created target-specific lures that it delivered to organizations in the form of Dropbox and WordPress URLs.?
Victims: Middle Eastern governments, foreign policy think tanks, and a state-affiliated airline

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian institutions and U.S. and European foreign policy institutions and think tanks
Description: Russian threat actor APT 28 targeted Ukrainian media organizations, government institutions, and foreign policy think tanks in the United States and the European Union with attempts to establish access to victims??systems, gain tactical information related to the invasion, and exfiltrate other sensitive information. Microsoft assumed control of seven of APT 28?? internet domains used in the attacks, redirecting site traffic to a sinkhole.
Victims: Ukrainian institutions including media organizations and government institutions and think tanks in the United States and the European Union involved in foreign policy

Title: Targeting of major telecommunications and network service providers
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Chinese government
Description: Chinese-backed threat actors identified vulnerabilities to gain access to major telecommunication companies and network service providers to access and exfiltrate victim data.
Victims: Public and private telecommunications providers and network service providers in the United States.

Title: APT 42
Description: APT 42 has a wide variety of targets and typically aims to access the networks of organizations and individuals who oppose the Iranian regime. Some overlap also exists between APT 42 and an Iranian-sponsored ransomware actor, UNC2448.
Victims: Think tanks, Western government officials, journalists, pharmaceutical companies, researchers, former Iranian government officials, Iranians living abroad, and countries such as the United States, Australia, Bulgaria, Iran, Israel, Italy, Malaysia, Norway

Title: Targeting of Amnesty International Canada
Affiliations:
Believed to be the work of the Chinese government
?
Description: Chinese threat actors compromised the networks of Amnesty International Canada to steal information on Amnesty's investigations into Chinese human rights abuses.

Title: Ukrainian IT Army
Description: The Ukrainian IT Army is a threat actor comprised of international and Ukrainian volunteer hackers working in collaboration with officials from Ukraine's defense ministry to target Russian infrastructure and websites. The IT Army is organized through a Telegram channel where new Russian targets are listed for volunteers to attack.?

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian, Latvian, and Lithuanian computer systems
Description: Russian threat actors targeted computer systems in Ukraine, Latvia, and Lithuania with a HermeticWiper malware attack. The malware was aimed at Windows devices, corrupting systems??master boot records, displaying signs of ransomware as a decoy, and destroying stored data.
Victims: Ukrainian, Latvian, and Lithuanian computer systems owned by banks and government contractors, as well as systems used by the defense, aviation, and IT sectors.

Title: Targeting of government, military, and energy sectors in Pakistan
Description: An Indian threat actor, Confucius, launched a spear-phishing campaign against military and government officials in Pakistan to steal information.
Victims: The government, military, and energy sectors in Pakistan

Title: Targeting of Myanmar government agencies
Description:
Mustang Panda launched a watering-hole attack by impersonating Burmese news outlets to gain access to Myanmar's government networks.
?

Title: Targeting of transportation companies via UEFI firmware implant
Description: The Winnti group is suspected of deploying an advanced Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) implant, dubbed Moonbounce, to the systems of a transportation company. Moonbounce is highly targeted and was likely created to access the networks of a small number of institutions and companies.?
Victims: A transportation company, as well as other targets

Title: Targeting of Viasat's satellite broadband service
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Russia's government
Description: The Russian military intelligence agency, known as GRU, targeted the internet provider Viasat?? satellite modems with a wiper that caused widespread communication outages??hroughout Ukraine on February 24, the same day Russian forces invaded the country.? The attack caused a loss in military communications at the start of the war and affected other government services. The outage also affected thousands of Viasat customers across Eastern and Central Europe.?
Victims: Users of Viasat's satellite broadband service in Eastern and Central Europe

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian agricultural firm
Description: Sandworm targeted a Ukrainian agricultural firm?? network by placing a file encryptor on its network, leaving it vulnerable to future destruction. Assessments indicate Sandworm intended to disrupt grain production and exports.

Title: Targeting of military and public institutions in Afghanistan and several east European countries
Description: The attackers sent phishing emails containing a malicious Microsoft Word document, which installed multiple Backdoors on targeted systems. The group likely used that access to conduct espionage.
Victims: Manufacturers of military products and military contractors in Afghanistan and Eastern Europe

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian local government organization
Description: Sandworm targeted Ukrainian local government networks in November 2022 with Caddywiper malware, which wipes most data on a system while preserving domain controllers. Researchers speculate this function allows Sandworm to maintain access inside networks after deploying Caddywiper.

Title: Targeting of the International Atomic Energy Agency and South Korean defense contractor
Description: The North Korean threat actor Kimsuky used spear-phishing techniques to masquerade as websites and applications to get victims to input their credentials. The victims included a security officer at the International Atomic Energy Agency.?
Victims: The International Atomic Energy Agency and Korea Aerospace Industries, a South Korean defense contractor

Title: Targeting of the Indian power grid
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Chinese government
Description: A Chinese state-sponsored threat actor targeted Indian power-grid organizations using ShadowPad malware. The actor intruded at least seven times into the networks of Indian State Load Despatch Centres, which oversee operations for grid control and electricity dispatch, particularly in North India. India claimed it had foiled the attack, while China denied it was behind the incident.
Victims: Indian power-grid assets, a national emergency response system, and the Indian subsidiary of a multinational logistics company

Title: Aoqin Dragon
Description: This Chinese threat actor has operated since 2013 and targets government, education, and telecommunication organizations in Australia and Southeast Asia. Aoqin Dragon seeks initial access primarily through document exploits and fake removable devices such as USB drives.
Victims: Government, education, and telecommunication organizations in Southeast Asia and Australia

Title: Targeting of organizations in an Iranian ransomware campaign
Description: Charming Kitten launched ransomware attacks against multiple organizations.
Victims: Organizations in the United States and Europe

Title: Targeting of U.S. satellite network
Description:
The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency said Russian cyber operatives had infiltrated the network of a U.S. satellite communications provider. How far the intrusion extended or what kind of information the Russians could have stolen remains unclear.
?

Title: Targeting of Russian diplomats in Asia
Description: The North Korean threat actor Konni launched a spear-phishing campaign against Russian diplomats in Indonesia. Konni spoofed the email address of the Russian embassy in Serbia to send a fake celebratory email that downloaded a remote access trojan once opened.?

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian government websites
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Russia's government
Description: Hackers for the Russian military intelligence agency, known as GRU, targeted the websites of the Ukrainian parliament, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Council of Ministers, and the Security Service of Ukraine with a DDoS attack that took the sites offline for two hours. A destructive wiper attack impacting hundreds of machines in Ukraine was reported simultaneously.?
Victims: The websites of the Ukrainian parliament, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Council of Ministers, and the Security Service of Ukraine

Title: Targeting of specialized engineering companies
Description: North Korean threat actor Lazarus Group targeted a specialized engineering company to steal sensitive intellectual property. The hackers breached the organization?? network by exploiting the Log4j vulnerability, moving laterally to compromise eighteen other computers. The hackers installed a backdoor to steal credentials and exfiltrate sensitive data.
Victims: Specialized engineering companies with customers in the military and energy sectors

Title: Targeting of U.S. political reporters and White House correspondents
Description: Since 2021, Zirconium, a Chinese threat actor, has carried out phishing attacks against U.S.-based journalists to uncover sensitive information about U.S. politics.
Victims: U.S. political reporters and White House correspondents

Title: Targeting of Japanese crypto-asset businesses
Description:
Lazarus, a North Korean state-sponsored hacking group, conducted several years of phishing attacks aimed at Japanese crypto-asset businesses to steal cryptocurrency.
?

Title: Targeting of German pharmaceutical and technology firms
Description: The Chinese group APT27 was detected launching attacks starting in 2021 against German companies. The attacks were primarily directed at technology and pharmaceutical firms. The group stole trade secrets and intellectual property and also aimed to use its access in certain companies to launch spear-phishing attacks against other targets.??
Victims: Pharmaceutical and technology companies in Germany

Title: Targeting of American news media and IT companies
Description: The Lazarus Group used a Google Chrome zero-day to target employees at American news media and IT companies. The Lazarus Group used phishing emails impersonating recruiters at Disney, Google, and Oracle with fake job opportunities, which included malicious links to spoofed Indeed and ZipRecruiter websites. An exploit kit hidden within the websites fingerprinted the target system and collected available client information.?
Victims: Over 250 individuals working for 10 different news media, domain registrars, web hosting providers, and software vendors

Title: Targeting of a Ukrainian transportation and logistics provider
Description: Sandworm targeted the network of a Ukrainian transportation and logistics provider with a destructive attack. The provider is based in western Ukraine, which is also where foreign military and humanitarian assistance enters the country, suggesting an intent to disrupt the movement of Ukrainian supplies to conflict hotspots.
Victims: A Ukrainian transportation and logistics provider

Title: Targeting of various industries with Maui ransomware
Description: The Lazarus Group used Maui ransomware to target government and civil institutions in order to raise money for the North Korean government.
Victims: Various industries, but primarily public health organizations in the United States

Title: Targeting of the Pakistani government
Description:
The threat actors behind Patchwork, an Indian APT, used spear-fishing tactics to install the Badnews backdoor and steal information from Pakistani government agencies.
?

Title: ModifiedElephant
Description: ModifiedElephant is a threat actor that has targeted activists, human rights defenders, journalists, academics, and law professionals in India for at least the past ten years. It primarily targets victims with remote access Trojans delivered through spear-phishing emails containing malicious file attachments. ModifiedElephant planted incriminating digital evidence used by Indian authorities to convict at least one activist of terrorism.?
Victims: Indian human rights activists, human rights defenders, academics, and lawyers

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian power stations
Description: Russian-linked Sandworm hackers targeted high-voltage electrical substations in Ukraine. The attackers used a novel variant of Industroyer malware, dubbed Industroyer2, which interacts with control systems that manage the flow of power. The hackers also deployed multiple strains of wiper malware as part of the attack.

Title: Targeting of telecommunications companies operating in Africa, Europe, and Southeast Asia
Description: Gallium, a Chinese APT, is thought to have operated since 2012 and primarily targets telecommunications companies, financial institutions, and governments. The group has previously used advanced, difficult-to-detect malware in its campaigns.
Victims: Telecommunications companies, financial institutions, and governments operating in Asia, Europe, and Southeast Asia

Title: Targeting of government officials in Europe, the Middle East, and South America
Description: Mustang Panda targeted government organizations in a phishing campaign. The campaign used PlugX, a frequently implemented Chinese modular malware tool.
Victims: Government organizations in Europe, the Middle East, and South America

Title: Targeting of European government trade departments
Description:
Chinese operators sent phishing emails disguised as memos on migration and trade policy to several different European governments. The campaign ran from September to November 2022 and utilized a new version of the modular PlugX malware.
?
Victims: European government departments focused on trade and migration policy

Title: Targeting of Pakistani research institutions
Description: An Indian threat actor was found using spear-phishing attacks against Pakistani targets, including the Ministry of Defense and several major research universities in the country. The threat actor had infected its own systems with the remote access trojan deployed in the attacks. This oversight allowed cybersecurity researchers to use the functions of the trojan to spy on the threat actor and understand its attack schemes and networks.?
Victims: Pakistan's Ministry of Defense, the National Defense University of Islamabad, the University of Veterinary and Anmial Sciences??Faculty of Bio-Science, the Karachi HEJ Research institute, and Salim Habib University.

Title: Targeting of American state governments' networks
Description: The Chinese cyber threat group APT41 conducted an extended campaign targeting the networks of at least six U.S. state governments. For over a year, APT41 exploited internet-facing web applications and leveraged a zero-day vulnerability in the USAHerds application used by many state governments, gaining access to the broader networks of state governments.?
Victims: The networks of at least six U.S. state governments

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian users of Chrome, Edge, and Firefox browsers
Description: Russian threat actor APT 28 targeted Ukrainian internet users with a new malware variant. The malware was sent to targets via email attachments titled ??a_report.zip.??When executed, the malware enables hackers to steal and exfiltrate cookies and saved passwords from Chrome, Edge, and Firefox browsers.
Victims: Ukrainian users of Chrome, Edge and Firefox browsers

Title: Targeting of the Ukrainian Azov Regiment
Description: Turla distributed Android-related malware disguised as an app that contributes to distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks against Russian websites. However, the application did not conduct DDoS attacks and instead provided Turla access to infected systems.
Victims: Ukrainian Azov Regiment and their supporters

Title: Targeting of companies in Hong Kong
Description:
Winnti Umbrella targeted government organizations in Hong Kong with malware to steal sensitive data from victims. The attacks are likely an expansion of Operation CuckooBees, previously documented in May 2022, which targeted businesses' networks in the United States and Europe to steal intellectual property.
?
Victims: Technology and manufacturing companies in Hong Kong

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian telecommunication company's internet service
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Russia's government
Description: Russian hackers targeted Ukrainian telecommunication company Ukrtelecom?? internet service, forcing users offline. Whether the malicious activity was a DDoS attack or a more sophisticated intrusion remains unclear. Service was restored fifteen hours after the initial compromise.?

Title: Red Menshen
Description: A Chinese threat actor believed to have used a custom backdoor to target telecommunications providers and entities in the government, education, and logistics sectors in the United States, Hong Kong, India, Myanmar, South Korea, Turkey, and Vietnam.
Victims: Telecommunications providers, government systems, postal and logistic systems, and others in the United States, Hong Kong, India, Myanmar, South Korea, Turkey, and Vietnam

Title: Targeting of Uyghur communities
Description: Chinese-affiliated group Poison Carp conducted a mobile surveillance campaign against Uyghurs in China and abroad using Android exploit and malware kit Moonshine. This is the second time Moonshine has reportedly been used; the first was in 2019 to surveil Tibetan activists.
Victims: Uyghurs both within and outside China

Title: Targeting of Australian media outlet
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of China's government
Description: Chinese hackers exploited the Log4Shell vulnerability in order to enter the systems of an Australian media outlet and access passwords and data.?

Title: Targeting of telecommunication companies, internet service providers, and the data services sector
Description: Chinese threat actor Hafnium targeted an un-patched zero-day vulnerability in Zoho products to implant a web shell. Hafnium exploited the Windows Task Scheduler to execute hidden scheduled tasks, allowing the malware to avoid detection.
Victims: Telecommunication companies, internet service providers, and the data services sector

Title: Targeting of high-level U.S. and Israeli officials
Description: Lyceum, an Iranian threat actor, used a newly developed and customized .NET-based malware that targeted government officials across the Middle East.
Victims: Government officials and Middle Eastern energy and telecommunications organizations

Title: Targeting of Montenegrin government infrastructure
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the government of the Russian Federation.
Description: Montenegro accused the Russian government of launching a widespread cyberattack against computer systems. The attack lasted several days and severely harmed several vital industries, including electricity and water systems, transportation networks, and online portals for state services. The U.S. embassy issued a warning to travelers in the country that immigration systems run by the Montenegrin government could have been affected by the hack.
Victims: Montenegrin government systems, including immigration systems

Title: Targeting of non-fungible token (NFT) owners
Description:
Lazarus Group targeted the owners of non-fungible tokens in a phishing campaign. The phishing sites allowed Lazarus to drain victims' accounts of both NFTs and cryptocurrencies.
?
Victims: NFT owners and NFT storage services

Title: Targeting of journalists in El Salvador
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of El Salvador's government.
Description: The Salvadoran government used NSO Group's Pegasus spyware to break into the phones of more than thirty five people. Among those targeted were at least twenty reporters investigating the government's ongoing negotiations with the criminal gang MS-13.?
Victims: Journalists and nongovernmental organizations in El Salvador

Title: Targeting of European diplomatic entities, research entities, and internet service providers
Description: The Chinese-linked threat actor Mustang Panda targeted European diplomatic entities with malicious files containing geopolitical themes, including a file titled ??ituation at the EU borders with Ukraine.zip.??The hackers used a European diplomat?? compromised email address to send the malware-laced emails to other countries??diplomatic offices.?
Victims: Search entities, internet service providers (ISPs), and European diplomatic missions mostly located in East and Southeast Asia.

Title: Targeting of a defense and cybersecurity organization in the Baltics
Description: Russian threat actor Turla targeted defense and cybersecurity organizations in the Baltic states. Turla sent emails to targets, each with unique links that led victims to download a malicious file.
Victims: A defense and cybersecurity organization in the Baltics

Title: Targeting of high-profile individuals at European embassies
Description: The Dukes sent out phishing emails to targets at European embassies to gain access to sensitive information.

Title: Targeting of Iranian citizens
Description: Iranian state-sponsored hacking group Prince of Persia targeted Iranian citizens for mobile surveillance by masking malware as an application that translates documents from English to Persian.

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian organizations and Western government entity
Description: Russian threat actor Gamaredon used spear-phishing emails and malware to target Ukrainian emergency response, security, and aid distribution organizations. In addition, Gamaredon presumably targeted a Western government entity in Ukraine.??
Victims: Government, military, nongovernment organizations, judiciary, law enforcement, and nonprofit groups in Ukraine

Title: Targeting of Indian government and military officials
Description: The threat actor APT36 targeted Indian government and military organizations with three malicious implants, including CrimsonRAT. APT36 used fake domains that mimicked legitimate government, military, and defense organizations in order to deliver malicious payloads.???,,Indian government and military officials"

Title: Targeting of telecommunications providers across the United States, Asia, and the Middle East
Description: Chinese threat actor Red Menshen used a custom backdoor dubbed BPFDoor to target telecommunications providers, government systems, postal and logistic systems, and others in the United States, Hong Kong, India, Myanmar, South Korea, Turkey, and Vietnam. Red Menshen moved laterally across Windows systems, sending commands via a virtual private server that were administered by compromised Taiwanese routers.
Victims: Telecommunications providers, government systems, postal and logistic system, and others in the United States, Hong Kong, India, Myanmar, South Korea, Turkey, and Vietnam

Title: Targeting of Israeli organizations using SysAid
Description: MuddyWater discovered a new way to utilize the Log4Shell vulnerability in attacks. The group used the Log4Shell bug in SysAid software, a commonly used IT management and help-desk tool, to access the networks of Israeli organizations.
Victims: Organizations in Israel running the SysAid IT management system

Title: Targeting of U.S. COVID relief funds
Description:
APT 41 targeted the U.S. Small Business Administration and stole at least $20 million in U.S. COVID relief benefits allocated to businesses in several different U.S. states.
?

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian banks and defense ministry
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Russia's government
Description: Russia targeted the Ukrainian defense ministry website and multiple banks with a DDoS attack, taking their sites offline and halting ATM service in some cases. Ukraine, the United States, and the United Kingdom attributed the attack to Russia, which denied the accusations.?

Title: Targeting of Axie Infinity?? Ronin Network
Description: The North Korea??inked Lazarus Group stole more than $600 million worth of cryptocurrency from the Axie Infinity video game. The hackers infiltrated Ronin Network, a decentralized finance platform used to earn and pay for in-game items with cryptocurrency. Lazarus then used a cryptocurrency mixer, Tornado Cash, to launder a portion of the stolen funds to avoid tracing and asset freezes. In response, the U.S. Treasury?? Office of Foreign Assets Control implemented sanctions against the Lazarus Group.
Victims: Users of decentralized finance platform Ronin Network

Title: Targeting of media stations such as newspapers and radio stations in Ukraine
Description: The Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) warned that Sandworm was exploiting the newly discovered Follina vulnerability in Microsoft Office to attack media organizations in the country.

Title: Targeting of an Asian IT provider
Description: Cybersecurity researchers identified a new campaign run by a Webworm, a Chinese cyber-espionage group. The campaign is in its early stages and appears to use publicly available malware to breach systems and steal information.
Victims: An IT provider operating in multiple Asian countries.

Title: Targeting of Asian government agencies and certificate authorities
Description: Chinese-affiliated APT Thrip compromised a digital certificate authority in an Asian country. Thrip likely used the certificates to sign malware used to target government agencies for the last six months.
Victims: Asian government agencies and one certificate authority

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian government websites
Description: The Ukrainian government accused Russia of defacing several government websites. Ukraine claimed that the cyberattack was intended as a false flag, as it utilized malware from an external ransomware group in an attempt to obfuscate attribution. The move came as Ukraine and Russia were locked in a state of heightened conflict, with the Ukrainian government accusing Russia of mounting a far larger campaign to place wipers on Ukrainian government systems that could be activated in the event of an invasion.?

Title: Targeting of Bahraini activists with Pegasus spyware
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Bahrain's government
Description: The Bahraini government used NSO Group?? Pegasus spyware to surveil the iPhones of at least three Bahraini activists. The NSO Group denied knowledge of the abuse.?
Victims: Bahraini activists, including a lawyer, an online journalist, and a mental health counselor

Title: Targeting of technology and manufacturing companies in Asia, Europe, and North America
Description: Chinese APT Winnti Umbrella targeted technology and manufacturing companies across Asia, Europe, and North America in a sophisticated cyber espionage campaign that began in 2019. Winnti used a novel strain of malware to exfiltrate the victims??intellectual property, including documents, blueprints, diagrams, formulas, and manufacturing-related proprietary data.
Victims: Technology and manufacturing companies in Asia, Europe, and North America.

Title: Targeting of the Belgian Federal Public Service Interior by Chinese threat actors
Description: Chinese threat actors targeted the Belgian Federal Public Service Interior as part of a wide-ranging cyber espionage campaign involving multiple threat actors. Belgian authorities condemned the activity.

Title: Targeting of Sri Lankan government
Description: Researchers found that Chinese-sponsored hacking group Winnti stole documents from the Sri Lankan government and remotely accessed software from August to October 2022.

Title: Targeting of German companies
Description: The Chinese group Emissary Panda installed malware inside the corporate networks of German companies. The actor may have attempted to steal business secrets and intellectual property, target customers, and use its access to the companies??networks to conduct a supply chain attack.?

Title: Targeting of Hungary's foreign ministry networks
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Russia's government
Description: Hackers from the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) and military intelligence agency, GRU, conducted a lengthy espionage campaign targeting Hungary?? foreign ministry networks. The initial infection was delivered via attachments in phishing emails and spread through the internal network, compromising more than 150 sites of more than 90 Hungarian foreign missions.???,,Hungary's foreign ministry networks"

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian organizations in phishing campaign
Description: APT 28 sent phishing emails masquerading as the Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) with the subject line "Cyberattack.??The email included a malware-laced attachment enabling APT 28 to gather and steal data.

Title: Targeting of South Korean diplomats, professors, and researchers
Description: Kimsuky was found launching spear-phishing attacks against numerous current and former South Korean diplomats and prominent foreign policy academics in South Korea.
Victims: Six professors at different universities in South Korea, three think tank researchers, the former South Korean ambassador to the UN, a prominent diplomat in the South Korean government, and a representative on the Research Council for North Korea

Title: Targeting of activists at Human Rights Watch, journalists, and politicians
Description:
Iran-affiliated threat actor Charming Kitten conducted a social-engineering and credential-phishing campaign targeting two Human Rights Watch staff members and at least eighteen other high-profile activists, journalists, researchers, academics, diplomats, and politicians working on Middle East issues in 2022.
?

Title: Targeting of American defense contractors
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Russia's government
Description: For at least two years spanning from January 2020 through February 2022, Russian state-sponsored threat actors targeted American cleared defense contractors (CDCs) to acquire and exfiltrate sensitive data and export-controlled technology. These CDCs were contracted by the Department of Defense (DoD) and the U.S. Intelligence Community in areas including command and control, intelligence, surveillance, and weapon development. Threat actors used brute force techniques to collect credentials and sent spear-phishing emails embedded with malicious links.?

Title: Targeting of South Korean chemical sector organizations
Description: In an extension of its Operation Dream Job campaign, North Korea?? Lazarus Group targeted individuals working at chemical sector organizations in South Korea. Lazarus used fake job-themed lures to bait victims into opening a malicious link and downloading malware used for cyber espionage.

Title: Targeting of Indian activists
Description: The Pune police department has been tied to a hacking campaign known as Modified Elephant. The Modified Elephant hackers are believed to have fabricated evidence of criminal wrongdoing before the arrest and trial of human rights activists known as the Bhima Koregaon 16.
Victims: Human rights activists in Pune, India

Title: Space Pirates
Description: Researchers identified a Chinese cyber-espionage group that has exchanged tools with Winnti Umbrella, APT 27, and Mustang Panda. The group has been observed using repurposed, publicly available malware in espionage campaigns throughout Asia since at least early 2022. The group could also be moonlighting as criminal hackers, as they have been observed attacking Chinese companies after typical work hours. ?
Victims: A multinational IT organization, and corporations and organizations in Georgia, Mongolia, and Russia

Title: Targeting of cryptocurrency start-ups
Description: BlueNoroff, an offshoot of the North Korean threat actor Lazarus Group, mounted a long-running campaign against cryptocurrency firms and exchanges in a bid to steal cryptocurrency.??

Title: Targeting   of entities   in Turkey   and the   Arabian   Peninsula
Description: MuddyWater?conducted a?campaign?targeting entities in Turkey and the?Arabian?Peninsula with?malicious?files??sed to?deliver a remote?access Trojan?called SloughRAT?to victim???computers.?These attacks,?though distinct,?are related to the?January 2022?MuddyWater?campaign?targeting the?Turkish?government,?leading experts?to conclude that?this Iranian APT?is comprised of multiple teams?operating?independently.?
Victims: Entities in Turkey and the Arabian Peninsula

Title: Targeting of diplomatic organizations in the Americas, Asia, and Europe
Description: Russian threat actor APT 29 targeted diplomatic entities with spear- phishing emails disguised as embassy administrative notices, which were sent from compromised email addresses of other diplomatic entities. The campaign used services such as Trello, Firebase, and Dropbox for command and control. Once the hackers infiltrated the target system, they established long-term access and collected sensitive diplomatic and foreign policy information.
Victims: Diplomatic organizations in the Americas, Asia, and Europe

Title: Targeting of Mexican journalists and human rights defenders
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Mexican government
Description: The Mexican government is reported to have used Pegasus spyware to conduct mobile surveillance operations against journalists and a human rights advocate between 2019 and 2022.
Victims: Mexican journalists and human rights advocates

Title: Targeting of Turkish government organizations
Description: The Iranian threat actor MuddyWater sent malicious PDFs and Microsoft Office documents posing as the Turkish Health and Interior Ministries. The campaign targeted government entities including the Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey (TUBITAK).?

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian organizations
Description: Russian threat actor Gamaredon targeted Ukrainian organizations in a phishing campaign. The hackers sent malicious emails with lures related to the Russia-Ukraine conflict, including attachments labeled ??nformation on war criminals of the Russian Federation??and ??ecessary_military_assistance.??The emails contained malware that allowed Russian operators to conduct espionage.
Victims: Ukrainian government and civil society organizations

Title: Targeting of Jordanian government
Description: Iranian threat actor APT 34 targeted Jordanian officials with the novel backdoor Saitama, which abuses the domain name system (DNS) protocol for command and control communications. Masquerading as the Government of Jordan, APT 34 sent an email via Microsoft Outlook with a malicious Excel document that contained the Saitama backdoor to other officials in the Jordanian government.
Victims: Government officials at Jordan?? foreign ministry

Title: Targeting of St. Petersburg Economic Forum
Description: The Ukrainian IT Army attacked the systems of the St. Petersburg Economic Forum in advance of Russian leader Vladimir Putin?? speech, delaying it for over an hour.
Victims: The computer systems of the St. Petersburg Economic Forum

Title: Targeting of the Burmese government and passport storage systems
Description:
Researchers discovered a compromised server being used by Mustang Panda as a temporary storage point for exfiltrated data, including recordings, webmail dumps, and scans of passports from American, Asian, and European citizens and diplomats applying for Burmese visas.
?
Victims: Burmese government agencies, and individuals who traveled to and within Myanmar

Title: Targeting of Taiwanese financial institutions
Description: The Chinese threat actor APT10 used a vulnerability in a web interface to install a version of the??uasar remote access Trojan. The attack was initially overlooked because of the focus on a credential stuffing attack, where hackers use mass amounts of previously stolen information to try to break into a system,?seemingly conducted by APT10 to secure access to trading accounts and make transactions on the Hong Kong stock market. The credential stuffing was used by APT10 as a smokescreen for its larger operation.?

Title: Targeting of UK government officials
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the United Arab Emirates government
Description: A United Arab Emirates??ponsored operator targeted networks belonging to the UK prime minister?? office and the Foreign and Commonwealth Office with Pegasus spyware. Multiple intrusions occurred in both 2020 and 2021.
Victims: UK government officials, including the office of Prime Minister Boris Johnson

Title: Targeting of Middle Eastern countries
Description: Since the last quarter of 2020, MuddyWater has maintained a campaign targeting countries in the Middle East. Samples of attacks were gathered from November 2020 to January 2022, but given the more recent samples found, this campaign could be currently active.

Title: Targeting of nuclear security researcher
Description: An expert in nuclear security was targeted as part of an Iranian spear-phishing campaign. The threat actors conversed at length with the target via email before sending a malicious document to the researcher.

Title: Targeting of Tibetan organizations
Description: Chinese APT Lucky Cat has been using a malicious Mozilla Firefox browser extension dubbed FriarFox to infiltrate and control targets??Gmail accounts. Primary objectives of the actor appear to be espionage and surveillance of dissidents, including the Tibetan diaspora.
Victims: Tibetan organizations and the Tibetan diaspora

Title: RedFoxTrot
Description: RedFoxTrot, a group associated with PLA Unit 69010, ran a long-term cyber espionage campaign since at least 2014 directed primarily toward countries in Central Asia, as well as Afghanistan, India, and Pakistan. The group is believed to operate out of Xinjiang.
Victims: Aerospace, mining, research, telecommunications, government, and military organizations in Afghanistan, India, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan.

Title: Targeting of Indian media organizations
Description: A Chinese threat actor was found using phishing attacks to gain access to the systems of several Indian media groups.

Title: Targeting of Uyghur activists, journalists, and dissidents
Description: The Chinese threat actor Evil Eye used fake Facebook profiles and websites that masqueraded as legitimate Turkish and Uyghur news sites to disseminate malicious links to Uyghur activists around the world.
Victims: Uyghur activists, journalists, and dissidents living in the United States, Australia, Canada, Kazakhstan, Syria, Turkey, and other countries

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian naval exercises
Description: Russian hackers were accused of defacing the Ukrainian Navy's website and uploading fake documents to spread disinformation about the annual Sea Breeze military exercises.

Title: Targeting of North Korean defectors and South Korean journalists
Description: North Korea conducted a spear-phishing campaign against North Korean defectors and South Korean journalists.?
Victims: South Korean journalists and North Korean defectors

Title: Confucius
Description: Indian APT believed to have targeted communications of government authorities in Pakistan and Kashmir.
Victims: Electoral officials in Kashmir and authorities linked to Pakistan?? nuclear agencies and military

Title: Targeting of Uyghurs in China and Pakistan
Description: Chinese hackers distributed malware pretending to be a UN document on funding for displaced Uyghurs. The hackers impersonated several UN websites for most of 2020 to spread the malware and communicate with infected systems.
Victims: Uyghurs living in Pakistan and China

Title: Targeting of Israeli entities
Description: As part of a broader espionage campaign spanning multiple countries, Chinese-linked APT UNC215 inserted malware into Israeli government computers to extract data

Title: Targeting of Japanese corporations
Description: Japanese corporations were targeted in a spear-phishing campaign launched by a Chinese threat actor. The campaign is likely focused on acquiring trade secrets from targeted companies.?
Victims: Japanese defense, media, and telecommunication companies

Title: Targeting of the defense industry
Description: North Korean APT Lazarus Group used a custom backdoor dubbed ThreatNeedle to laterally move through infected defense firm networks and gather sensitive information in over a dozen countries. The actor achieved initial entry to victim networks through spear-phishing emails with malicious attachments or links.
Victims: Defense firms in more than a dozen countries

Title: Targeting of South Korean nuclear research center
Description: South Korea's nuclear research center detected an intrusion into its systems in the middle of May 2021, but was able to remove the malicious code from its VPN before it could be executed.

Title: Targeting of Afghan telecommunication firm Roshan
Description: An email server controlled by the Afghan telecommunication company Roshan was targeted by a Chinese threat actor since at least July 2020. RedFoxTrot was also identified targeting other unnamed Afghan telecommunication companies during the same period.
Victims: Roshan and other major Afghan telecommunication companies

Title: Targeting of Malwarebytes??Office 365 tenant
Description: The same threat actor that compromised SolarWinds abused applications with privileged access to Microsoft 365 and Azure environments, granting the actor access to a limited subset of Malwarebytes??internal emails.

Title: Targeting of U.S. and Israeli medical researchers
Description: The Iranian threat actor Charming Kitten targeted medical researchers in the United States and Israel with spear-phishing techniques. The threat actor used a malicious Gmail account masquerading as a prominent Israeli physicist to trick targets into downloading malware.
Victims: Less than twenty-five senior medical professionals at a variety of institutions in the United States and Israel

Title: Targeting of civil society groups in Nepal, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Hong Kong
Description: Chinese state-sponsored hackers were detected infiltrating networks in Nepal, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Hong Kong, with a focus on academic and governmental networks.
Victims: Governments, academics, and research and development institutions across Nepal, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Hong Kong

Title: Targeting of South Korean company recruiters
Description: Hackers from the North Korean Lazarus Group sent malware disguised as job openings at Samsung to engineers. These attacks followed a methodology similar to that of a July 2021 Lazarus Group campaign against engineering firms in South Korea.?
Victims: Engineers were targeted in the hopes that Lazarus Group would access the systems of South Korean engineering and defense companies.

Title: Domestic Kitten
Description: Iranian APT believed to be primarily involved in domestic surveillance.
Victims: Internal dissidents, opposition forces, self-proclaimed Islamic State advocates, and Kurds, among others

Title: Targeting of U.S. Agency for International Development
Description: The Russian hacking group Nobelium compromised the company hosting the servers for the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) and used its access to send phishing emails to other aid groups.

Title: Targeting of manufacturing groups across Asia
Description: The Pakistani-linked APT Aggah launched a spear-phishing campaign in early 2021 that targeted manufacturing firms in Taiwan and South Korea, as well as other countries.
Victims: Manufacturing companies in Taiwan and South Korea.

Title: Targeting of various industries through Gmail compromises
Description: APT28 was detected conducting a wide-ranging phishing attack against more than fourteen thousand Gmail users who work as activists, journalists, and national security officials.?
Victims: More than fourteen thousand Gmail users who work as activists, journalists, or national security professionals.

Title: Targeting of India?? power infrastructure
Description: Amid mounting border tensions between China and India in 2020, Chinese threat actors allegedly infected India?? power grid?? control systems with malware.

Title: Targeting of Polish members of parliament's email accounts
Description: In a campaign known as Ghostwriter, Polish politicians' personal email accounts were targeted by hackers who stole classified documents. The Polish government has said Russia was behind the attack, a claim disputed by Mandiant, which attributes the attack to Belarus.

Title: Calypso
Description: Calypso has been observed targeting government agencies worldwide since 2016, including institutions in Brazil, Indonesia, Russia, Thailand, and Turkey. The group was also implicated in a breach of Afghan telecommunication company Roshan.
Victims: Roshan, a major Afghan telecommunication company, as well asgovernment agencies in Brazil, Indonesia, Russia, Thailand, and Turkey

Title: Targeting of security researchers with malware
Description: North Korean hackers used spear-phishing social media techniques to target security researchers to install malware onto targets??Windows systems.?

Title: Targeting of the Vietnamese and Thai governments and military
Description: APT 27 conducted a wide-ranging espionage campaign to gather data from a variety of institutions throughout Southeast Asia, primarily concentrated in Vietnam.
Victims: Vietnamese government, military, and civil society institutions along with comparable institutions in Thailand

Title: Targeting of academics focusing on the Middle East
Description: Charming Kitten was found using spear-phishing attacks against UK experts who study the Middle East. The attacks involved impersonating scholars from the University of London's School of Oriental and African Studies and prompted the victims to either turn over sensitive information or download malware onto their systems.
Victims: Researchers in the United Kingdom focused on the Middle East

Title: Targeting of Afghan government and military
Description: A Pakistani threat actor launched a series of spear-phishing attacks against the Afghan government. The attackers stole personal information from high-level diplomats and military officials, including names, email addresses, and diplomatic visa forms.?

Title: Targeting of domestic citizens in Iran
Description: Iranian APT Domestic Kitten used spyware FurBall to surveil domestic citizens and anyone considered a threat to Tehran. Campaigns have been ongoing since 2017, with the latest launched in November 2020.
Victims: Internal dissidents, opposition forces, self-proclaimed Islamic State advocates, and Kurds, among others

Title: Targeting of South Korean government
Description: The South Korean government was targeted in a wide-ranging attack by North Korean threat actors. The attacks installed the AppleSeed backdoor, which was used to exfiltrate information.
Victims: South Korean Ministry of Trade, Industry, and Energy; South Korean Ministry of Foreign Affairs; Consulate of South Korea in Hong Kong; and the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Seoul

Title: Targeting of Air India
Description: While investigating a breach of Air India's data systems, cybersecurity researchers stumbled on a previously undetected intrusion into Air India's systems likely carried out by Chinese threat actors.

Title: Targeting of South Korean think tank
Description: Using an unusual route to gain access to civil society and government groups, North Korean hackers accessed the servers of a South Korean think tank by compromising a Latvian company providing third-party services.?
Victims: A Latvian technology company and a South Korean think tank

Title: Targeting of organizations via Microsoft Exchange Server vulnerability
Description: The Chinese threat actor Hafnium exploited vulnerabilities in the Microsoft Exchange Server to access the emails of hundreds of thousands of entities across the globe.
Victims: Various industry sectors, including state and local governments, universities, defense contractors, law firms, medical researchers, think tanks, and others

Title: Targeting of Norwegian government's IT network
Description: An investigation by the Norwegian Police Security Service (PST) found that a 2018 breach of the government's IT systems was carried out by a Chinese threat actor. The hackers removed large amounts of data in the breach, although the PST is still unsure of exactly how much data or what files were taken
Victims: Norwegian government and its IT system

Title: Targeting of Afghan telecommunication firm Roshan
Description: An email server controlled by the Afghan telecommunication company Roshan was targeted by a Chinese threat actor since at least early 2021. Calypso?? data exfiltration activity spiked in August and September 2021, coinciding with the United States military?? withdrawal from Afghanistan.
Victims: Roshan, a major Afghan telecommunication company

Title: Take down of EMOTET botnet
Affiliations: Law enforcement agencies in the United States, Canada, France, Germany, Lithuania, the Netherlands, Ukraine, and United Kingdom
Description: An international coalition of law enforcement authorities successfully took down notorious criminal botnet EMOTET by taking control of its command-and-control servers.
Sponsor: United States, Canada, France, Germany, Lithuania, Netherlands, Ukraine, United Kingdom

Title: Targeting of South African freight companies
Description: Vyveva, a known Lazarus Group malware tool, was spotted in the systems of South African shipping companies. The malware appears designed to facilitate file transfers.

Title: Targeting of Philippine and Nepalese governments
Description: Kaspersky Labs detected a high-volume campaign in Southeast Asia primarily aimed at government agencies in Myanmar, Nepal, and the Philippines. The attackers used a compromised version of the popular video conference application Zoom to break into computers.
Victims: Government agencies in Myanmar, Nepal, and the Philippines

Title: Targeting of Pfizer vaccine data
Description: South Korean lawmaker Ha Tae-keung told reporters that North Korean hackers attempted to steal COVID-19 vaccine data from U.S. pharmaceutical company Pfizer. It is unclear whether the alleged operation was successful.

Title: Targeting of Myanmar's presidential website
Description: The Chinese hacking group Red Echo inserted malicious code into a download link on the webpage for Myanmar's president. This marks the second time Myanmar?? presidential website has been used in watering-hole attacks by Chinese hackers.

Title: Targeting of Slovakian government agencies
Description: Nobelium launched spear-phishing attacks against Slovakian diplomats by posing as the Slovak National Security Authority.

Title: Emennet Pasargad
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Iranian government.
Description: An Iranian company hired by the Iranian government to interfere in U.S. elections. Emennet Pasargad has attacked voting-related websites and news outlets and distributed misinformation designed to undermine confidence in the U.S. electoral system.?
Victims: Organizations related to the U.S. electoral process and news outlets.

Title: Hafnium
Description: The Chinese APT believed to be behind the exploitation of vulnerabilities in the Microsoft Exchange email server to access user emails. Historically, Hafnium has primarily targeted entities in the United States.
Victims: Various industry sectors, including state and local governments, universities, defense contractors, law firms, medical researchers, think tanks, and others

Title: Targeting of government and energy organizations in India and Afghanistan
Description: Pakistani threat actors compromised Indian government organizations and energy suppliers with open-source remote access Trojan horses.
Victims: Indian government agencies and energy providers

Title: Targeting of South Korean companies with ransomware
Description: North Korean hackers launched ransomware attacks on South Korean businesses. The malware used is an old incarnation of Lazarus Group?? espionage tools with added ransomware functionality.?

Title: Disruption of NetWalker ransomware
Affiliations: Federal Bureau of Investigation, Bulgarian National Investigative Service
Description: U.S. and Bulgarian authorities disrupted the NetWalker ransomware in a coordinated effort that disabled dark web resources and led to the arrest of a Canadian citizen and the seizure of approximately $500,000 in cryptocurrency delivered by victims as ransomware payments.

Title: Targeting of Lebanese job seekers
Description: Lebanese job seekers were sent a compromised pdf document claiming to be an offer from an American IT firm. The exact targets of this phishing campaign remain unclear.

Title: Targeting of U.S. defense industry using Facebook
Description: Iran was accused of attempting to break into the personal accounts of over two hundred senior defense personnel in the United States and United Kingdom. The individuals were targeted in phishing attacks.
Victims: Individuals in the defense industry in the United States and United Kingdom

Title: Targeting of French public organizations
Description: Nobelium, a Russian threat actor, is believed to have compromised the servers of several French organizations as early as February 2021 to launch spear-phishing attacks against foreign organizations.?
Victims: French civil society organizations with significant foreign ties.

Title: Targeting of French IT monitoring company
Description: Russian APT Sandworm used two different malware strains to hack the IT monitoring software of French cybersecurity firm Centreon. The hacking campaign lasted from 2017 to 2020 and only affected entities using the open-source version of Centreon?? software.
Victims: Fifteen entities, including France?? Ministry of Justice, that used Centreon?? outdated, open-source services

Title: Targeting of Southeast Asian ministry of foreign affairs
Description: A South Asian government was targeted as part of a long-running cyber espionage campaign carried out by a Chinese threat actor. The campaign used spear phishing to drop malware onto the government's systems.

Title: Watering-hole attack on popular North Korean news site

The threat actors used an exploit, called EternalBlue--first discovered by the U.S. National Security Agency--to propagate WannaCry in organizations using the Windows operating system.?On December 19, 2017, the United States, Australia, Canada, Japan, and the United Kingdom?issued statements accusing North Korea of being responsible for WannaCry.

An administrative network of the Wolf Creek Nuclear Operating Corporation was compromised.

A threat actor targets the worldwide financial transfer mechanism known as SWIFT to steal funds from banks in Bangladesh, Vietnam, Ecuador, and Poland. This is the first instance in where a state-sponsored actor was discovered to have compromised networks for financial gain.
